did.abstract: These are chiefly letters to members of his family on the business of the museums in Philadelphia, New York, and London. The letters of 1824 are press copies, chiefly to Charles Willson Peale and Benjamin Franklin Peale about the Baltimore museum.

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: These two letterbooks contain the correspondence of Reubens Peale primarily to his family. One dates from 1802-1814. In it, Reubens discusses a variety of topics. Some letters describe his social life and current events, while many others deal with museum issues. One letter, written from England, details a magic trick he witnessed that he thought would be popular in the museum.

The second volume (b) is much smaller and contains carbon copies of letters dated from Baltimore in 1824. These letters are primarily to family members and sometimes business associates. They chronicle Reubens’ life as the head of the Baltimore Museum.

odd.head: Administrative Note
odd.p: This record is superseded by, and included in, B P31. It was marked “internal only” in Dec., 2010 and is being kept in the case that it is needed for future administrative needs.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Rubens Peale managed his father's museum in Philadelphia from 1810 to 1822. At that time, he bought his brother Rembrandt's controlling interest in the Peale Museum in Baltimore. He also opened branches in New York City and in Utica, New York. He eventually sold his collection to P. T. Barnum.
